article:
Lata Mangeshkar

Lata Mangeshkar (September 28, 1929 – February 6, 2022) was an Indian playback singer and a prominent figure in the Indian music industry. With a career spanning over seven decades, she is widely regarded as one of the greatest singers of all time, known for her unique voice and versatility in singing various genres of music.

#Early life

Lata Mangeshkar was born in Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India, to a musical family. Her father, Pandit Deenanath Mangeshkar, was a classical singer and a composer, and her mother, Shevanti Mangeshkar, was a singer and a musician. Lata was the eldest of four siblings, including Asha Bhosle, Hridayanath Mangeshkar, and Usha Mangeshkar. Her family moved to Mumbai when Lata was just ten years old, and she began her singing career at the age of 13.

#Singing career

##Early career in the 1940s

Lata's singing career began in the 1940s, when she started performing in local radio shows and concerts. Her early singing style was influenced by her father, who was a classical singer and a composer. She began to gain recognition in the late 1940s, singing for films such as "Mashaal" (1943) and "Gajaabaa" (1943).

##1950s

In the 1950s, Lata's popularity as a playback singer began to grow. She sang for films such as "Anandmath" (1952), "Bhagwan" (1954), and "Aasha" (1957). She also began to experiment with different genres of music, including devotional and folk music. Her singing style during this period was characterized by her unique voice and versatility.

##1960s

The 1960s were a pivotal period in Lata's career, during which she sang for some of the most iconic films of the era. She sang for films such as "Jai Santoshi Maa" (1962), "Dil Apna Aur Preet Parai" (1964), and "Sangam" (1964). She also began to work with prominent music directors such as Shankar-Jaikishan and Roshan.

##1970s

In the 1970s, Lata's popularity continued to grow, and she sang for films such as "Bobby" (1973), "Namak Haraam" (1973), and "Amar Prem" (1972). She also began to explore new genres of music, including disco and rock. Her singing style during this period was characterized by her ability to adapt to new styles and genres.

##1980s

The 1980s saw Lata's popularity wax and wane, as new playback singers such as Alka Yagnik and Anuradha Paudwal began to gain recognition. However, Lata continued to sing for films such as "Kalyug" (1981), "Prem Rog" (1982), and "Betaab" (1983). She also began to work with prominent music directors such as Laxmikant-Pyarelal and Bappi Lahiri.

##1990s

In the 1990s, Lata's career experienced a resurgence, as she sang for films such as "Hum Aapke Hain Koun..!" (1994), "Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" (1995), and "Kuch Kuch Hota Hai" (1998). She also began to work with new music directors, including Sanjeev-Darshan and A. R. Rahman.

##2000s

The 2000s saw Lata's continued dominance in the Indian music industry. She sang for films such as "Lagaan" (2001), "Devdas" (2002), and "Black" (2005). She also began to explore new genres of music, including fusion and experimental music.

##2010s

In the 2010s, Lata's career continued to thrive, as she sang for films such as "Rang De Basanti" (2006), "Jab Tak Hai Jaan" (2012), and "Bajirao Mastani" (2015). She also began to work with new music directors, including Shankar-Ehsaan-Loy and Vishal-Shekhar.

##2020s

In the 2020s, Lata's career continued to be marked by her versatility and ability to adapt to new styles and genres. She sang for films such as "Sholay" (2020) and "KGF 2" (2022). She also continued to work with prominent music directors, including A. R. Rahman and Sanjay-Leela Bhansali.

##Bengali career

Lata's career in Bengali films began in the 1950s, when she sang for films such as "Shapmochan" (1954) and "Nishpap" (1954). She continued to sing for Bengali films throughout her career, including films such as "Ganadevata" (1978) and "Jhinder Bandi" (1992).

#Collaboration with other singers

Lata collaborated with many other singers throughout her career, including Asha Bhosle, Mohammed Rafi, and Kishore Kumar. She also collaborated with foreign singers, including American singers such as Elvis Presley and British singer Cliff Richard.

#Non-singing career

##Music direction

In addition to her singing career, Lata also worked in music direction. She composed music for films such as "Anjali" (1970) and "The Burning Train" (1980). She also worked with prominent music directors, including Laxmikant-Pyarelal and Kalyanji-Anandji.

##Production

Lata also worked in film production. She produced films such as "Ram Tere Kitne Nam" (1985) and "Anjaam Pyaar Ka" (1986). She also worked with prominent producers, including B. R. Chopra and Yash Chopra.

#Illness and death

Lata Mangeshkar was hospitalized several times throughout her career due to various illnesses, including pneumonia and a heart attack. She passed away on February 6, 2022, at the age of 92, due to complications from COVID-19.

#Awards and recognition

Lata Mangeshkar received numerous awards and recognition throughout her career, including the Padma Bhushan in 1969, the Padma Vibhushan in 1999, and the Bharat Ratna in 2001. She also received numerous Filmfare Awards, including the Best Female Singer award a record 12 times.

#Controversy

Lata Mangeshkar was involved in several controversies throughout her career, including a lawsuit with music director Roshan over royalties and a public feud with singer Asha Bhosle over their respective careers.

#Footnotes

Death and Funeral of Pope Benedict XVI

Pope Benedict XVI, the Pope emeritus of the Catholic Church, passed away on December 31, 2022, at the age of 95, at the Mater Ecclesiae Monastery in the Vatican City. His death marked the end of an era in the Catholic Church, as he was the first Pope to resign in nearly 600 years.

Background
----------

Pope Benedict XVI had been in poor health for several years prior to his death, suffering from various ailments, including mobility issues and a partial paralysis of his right hand. Despite his poor health, he continued to serve the Catholic Church as Pope emeritus, offering guidance and support to his successor, Pope Francis.

Last days
----------

In the days leading up to his death, Pope Benedict XVI's health continued to deteriorate, and he was confined to his bed at the Mater Ecclesiae Monastery. According to officials, he passed away peacefully at 9:34 am local time, surrounded by his staff and caregivers.

Death

Pope Benedict XVI's death was confirmed by the Vatican later that day, with officials releasing a statement announcing his passing. The statement described his death as a "pivotal moment" in the life of the Catholic Church, and praised his contributions to the Church during his nearly eight-year papacy.

The funeral of Pope Benedict XVI was held on January 5, 2023, at St. Peter's Square in the Vatican City. The ceremony was a grand and solemn affair, with thousands of mourners attending to pay their respects to the deceased Pope.

**East Palestine, Ohio, Train Derailment**

The East Palestine, Ohio, train derailment was a major rail accident that occurred on February 3, 2023, in East Palestine, a village in Columbiana County, Ohio. A Norfolk Southern freight train carrying hazardous materials derailed, causing a massive fire and environmental concerns. The incident raised questions about the safety of rail transportation, the handling of hazardous materials, and the response to emergencies.

**Background**

East Palestine, with a population of around 4,500, is a small village located near the Pennsylvania border. The Norfolk Southern Railway, one of the largest railroads in the United States, has a significant presence in the area. The village has a rich history, dating back to the late 19th century, and has been an important hub for rail transportation.

The Norfolk Southern Railway has been operating in the area for over a century, with a significant portion of its traffic passing through East Palestine. The village has a rail yard and a rail maintenance facility, which employ many local residents. The proximity of the rail line to residential areas has raised concerns about the safety of rail transportation.

**Derailment**

On the evening of February 3, 2023, a Norfolk Southern freight train carrying hazardous materials derailed near East Palestine. The train, which was traveling from Chicago to Selkirk, New York, had 14 cars, including five tank cars carrying vinyl chloride, a highly flammable and toxic chemical. The derailment occurred on a curve, causing the train to break apart and release its hazardous cargo.

The fire that erupted from the derailment was massive, with flames reaching up to 100 feet high. The fire was fueled by the vinyl chloride, which is highly flammable. The fire department responded quickly, but the situation was complicated by the presence of hazardous materials.

**Emergency response and burn off**

The emergency responders, including the fire department and the hazardous materials team, worked to contain the fire and prevent the spread of hazardous materials. However, their efforts were hindered by the fact that the vinyl chloride was still burning, releasing toxic fumes into the air.

The decision was made to conduct a controlled burn, known as a "burn off," to eliminate the remaining hazardous materials. The burn off was carried out by the fire department, with the assistance of the hazardous materials team.

**Burn off unnecessary**

However, some experts have questioned the need for the burn off, citing concerns about the potential health risks and environmental impact. The burn off released large quantities of toxic fumes into the air, which were carried by the wind and affected nearby communities.

The burn off also raised concerns about the handling of hazardous materials, as it was not clear whether the procedure was necessary or whether it was a precautionary measure. The incident highlighted the need for better communication and coordination between emergency responders and regulatory agencies.

**Health and environmental concerns**

The derailment and subsequent burn off raised significant health and environmental concerns. The vinyl chloride released during the incident is a known carcinogen and can cause a range of health problems, including respiratory issues and cancer.

The burn off also released large quantities of particulate matter, including fine particles and heavy metals, which can exacerbate respiratory issues and other health problems. The incident highlighted the need for better regulation of rail transportation and the handling of hazardous materials.

**Waste disposal**

The vinyl chloride released during the derailment was disposed of through a burn off, which was carried out by the fire department. However, the disposal process raised concerns about the potential environmental impact and the effectiveness of the burn off in eliminating the hazardous materials.

The disposal of hazardous materials is a critical issue, as it can have significant environmental and health consequences. The incident highlighted the need for better regulation and oversight of waste disposal practices.

**Independent testing**

In the aftermath of the derailment, independent testing was conducted to determine the extent of the environmental damage. The testing revealed that the burn off had released large quantities of toxic fumes, including vinyl chloride and particulate matter.

The testing also revealed that the burn off had caused significant environmental damage, including the contamination of soil and water. The incident highlighted the need for better regulation and oversight of environmental practices.

**Whistleblower and cover-up allegations**

There have been allegations of a cover-up in the aftermath of the derailment. Some experts have questioned the need for the burn off and the handling of hazardous materials, citing concerns about the potential health risks and environmental impact.

Endorsements in the 2023 Australian Indigenous Voice Referendum

The 2023 Australian Indigenous Voice Referendum was a national vote held on 14 October 2023, to determine whether the Australian constitution should be amended to enshrine an Indigenous Voice to Parliament. The referendum was the culmination of a long-standing campaign by Indigenous Australians to have their voices heard and represented in the Australian government. The referendum was accompanied by a significant amount of public engagement and debate, with many individuals and organizations taking a stance on the proposed constitutional amendment.

#Yes campaign

##Lead lobby groups

The Yes campaign for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament was led by several prominent lobby groups, including the First Nations Foundation, the Australian Indigenous Leadership Centre, and the National Congress of Australia's First Peoples. These organizations worked tirelessly to raise awareness about the importance of the Indigenous Voice and to build support for the proposed constitutional amendment.

##Politicians

###Federal

Several federal politicians publicly endorsed the Yes campaign, including the Prime Minister, Anthony Albanese, who stated that the Indigenous Voice was essential for reconciliation and a more just society. Other federal politicians who endorsed the Yes campaign included Indigenous Affairs Minister, Linda Burney, and Senator Malarndirri McCarthy. 

###State and territory

State and territory politicians also endorsed the Yes campaign, with several premiers and chief ministers announcing their support for the Indigenous Voice. # Cornish Bronze Age

The Cornish Bronze Age, spanning from approximately 2400 to 800 BCE, was a period of significant cultural, economic, and social development in the region that is now Cornwall, in the southwestern tip of England. This article provides an overview of the chronology, settlements, structures, subsistence, ritual, metal exploitation, crafts, amber, glass, and faience, art, trade and cultural networks, social organization, environment and ecology, and ethnicity, genetics, and language of the Cornish Bronze Age.

## Chronology

The Cornish Bronze Age is typically divided into several distinct periods, each with its own characteristic cultural and technological developments.

### Bell Beaker period (c. 2400–1700 BCE)

The Bell Beaker period in Cornwall is characterized by the introduction of the distinctive bell-shaped beaker pottery, which was likely brought by migrant groups from the European mainland. This period saw the establishment of early farming communities, with a focus on cereal cultivation and animal husbandry.

### Early Bronze Age (c. 2050–1500 BCE)

The Early Bronze Age in Cornwall is marked by the introduction of metalworking, with the use of copper and bronze for toolmaking and other purposes. This period also saw the development of more complex farming systems and the establishment of small settlements.

### Middle Bronze Age (c. 1500–1100 BCE)

The Middle Bronze Age in Cornwall is characterized by a significant increase in the use of metal, particularly bronze, for toolmaking and other purposes. This period also saw the development of more complex social systems, with the emergence of wealthy elites and the establishment of trade networks.

### Late Bronze Age (c. 1100–800 BCE)

The Late Bronze Age in Cornwall is marked by a period of significant cultural and economic change. This period saw the introduction of new technologies, including the development of ironworking, and the establishment of more complex trade networks.

**PAOK FC**

PAOK Football Club, commonly referred to as PAOK, is a Greek professional football club based in Thessaloniki, Greece. The club was founded in 1926 and has a rich history, having won numerous domestic and international titles. PAOK is one of the most successful and popular football clubs in Greece, with a devoted fan base and a reputation for being a major force in the country's football scene.

**#History**

### **Foundation and early years (1926–1939)**

PAOK was founded on March 20, 1926, by a group of football enthusiasts in Thessaloniki. The club's early years were marked by modest success, with PAOK winning the Thessaloniki Football Championship in 1929. During this period, the club's home games were played at the Harilaou Stadium, which was the main football stadium in Thessaloniki at the time.

### **Greco-Italian War and World War II (1939–1945)**

The Greco-Italian War broke out in 1940, and PAOK's activities were severely disrupted. The club's stadium was destroyed during the war, and many of its players were called up to fight. After the war, PAOK resumed its activities, but the club's fortunes were not as good as before. The team struggled to regain its footing, and it was not until the late 1940s that PAOK began to experience a resurgence.

### **Macedonia Football Clubs Association (Macedonia Championship) (1946–1959)**

In 1946, the Macedonia Football Clubs Association was established, and PAOK became one of its founding members. The club won several championships during this period, including the Macedonia Championship in 1949. This was a significant achievement for PAOK, which helped to establish the club as a major force in Greek football.

### **Toumba Stadium and rise of Giorgos Koudas to prominence (1959–1969)**

In 1959, PAOK moved to its new home stadium, the Toumba Stadium. The stadium was a significant improvement over the club's previous home, and it helped to establish PAOK as a major force in Greek football. During this period, the club experienced a significant increase in success, with Giorgos Koudas becoming the club's star player. Koudas was a talented midfielder who helped to lead PAOK to several championships, including the Greek National Championship in 1963.

### **First years in Greek National League (Alpha Ethniki)**

PAOK's first year in the Greek National League was in 1959, when the club finished second in the championship. This was a significant achievement for the club, which marked the beginning of a successful period in Greek football. In the following years, PAOK continued to experience success, winning several championships and establishing itself as a major force in Greek football.

### **Giorgos Koudas debut and start of the Olympiacos–PAOK rivalry**

Giorgos Koudas made his debut for PAOK in 1959, and he quickly became the club's star player. Koudas was a talented midfielder who helped to lead PAOK to several championships, including the Greek National Championship in 1963. During this period, the club also established a rivalry with Olympiacos, which would become one of the most famous rivalries in Greek football.

### **1970s**

The 1970s were a successful period for PAOK, with the club winning several championships, including the Greek National Championship in 1976. This was a significant achievement for the club, which marked the beginning of a new era of success in Greek football.

### **1975–76 Alpha Ethniki (first league title)**

PAOK's first league title was in 1976, when the club finished first in the Alpha Ethniki. This was a significant achievement for the club, which marked the beginning of a new era of success in Greek football.

### **1980s: Professionalism, league title and financial troubles**

The 1980s were a significant period for PAOK, with the club experiencing both success and financial troubles. During this period, the club won several championships, including the Greek National Championship in 1985. However, the club also struggled with financial problems, which would continue to plague the club for many years.

### **1984–85 Alpha Ethniki (second league title)**

PAOK's second league title was in 1985, when the club finished first in the Alpha Ethniki. This was a significant achievement for the club, which marked the beginning of a new era of success in Greek football.

### **The Thomas Voulinos era (1989–1996)**

Thomas Voulinos was a significant figure in PAOK's history, who served as the club's president from 1989 to 1996. During this period, the club experienced significant success, including the Greek National Championship in 1990.

### **The George Batatoudis era (1996–2003)**

George Batatoudis was a significant figure in PAOK's history, who served as the club's president from 1996 to 2003. During this period, the club experienced significant success, including the Greek National Championship in 1997.

### **The Giannis Goumenos era: troubled times (2003–2006)**

Giannis Goumenos was a significant figure in PAOK's history, who served as the club's president from 2003 to 2006. During this period, the club experienced significant financial troubles, which would continue to plague the club for many years.

### **Theodoros Zagorakis – Zisis Vryzas management with massive fans' support (2007–2012)**

Theodoros Zagorakis and Zisis Vryzas were a significant management duo in PAOK's history, who served as the club's coach and president from 2007 to 2012. During this period, the club experienced significant success, including the Greek National Championship in 2009.

### **The Ivan Savvidis era (2012–present)**

Ivan Savvidis is a significant figure in PAOK's history, who has served as the club's president since 2012. During this period, the club has experienced significant success, including the Greek National Championship in 2019.

### **2017–18 eventful season**

The 2017-18 season was an eventful one for PAOK, which finished second in the Greek National Championship. The club also reached the quarterfinals of the UEFA Europa League, where it was eliminated by Chelsea.

### **2018–19 unbeaten Champions and first Domestic Double**

The 2018-19 season was a significant one for PAOK, which finished unbeaten in the Greek National Championship. The club also won its first domestic double, winning both the championship and the Greek Cup.

### **2020–21 Greek Cup winners and 2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League quarter-finalists**

article:
**September 2022 United Kingdom mini-budget**

The September 2022 United Kingdom mini-budget was a fiscal policy package announced by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kwasi Kwarteng, on 23 September 2022, during the UK's cost of living crisis. The budget included a series of tax cuts and announcements aimed at stimulating economic growth, which sparked controversy and criticism from various quarters.

**Background**

The UK was facing a severe cost of living crisis, with rising inflation and energy prices causing hardship for many households. The Conservative Party government, led by Prime Minister Liz Truss, had promised to tackle the crisis and boost economic growth. The mini-budget was seen as a key part of this strategy, aimed at stimulating investment and economic activity.

**The budget**

The mini-budget included several key measures:

### **Key points**

* A 5% cut in income tax rates, reducing the basic rate of income tax from 20% to 19% and the higher rate from 40% to 39%
* A cut in the corporation tax rate from 26% to 25%
* A abolition of the 45% top rate of income tax
* A reversal of a planned increase in National Insurance Contributions (NICs)
* A £150 billion package of tax cuts and incentives aimed at stimulating economic growth

These measures were seen as a significant shift in the government's economic policy, away from austerity and towards a more expansionary approach.

**Reaction**

The mini-budget sparked a wide range of reactions from across the UK and beyond.

### **Currency, interest rate, and debt**

The announcement of the mini-budget caused a sharp fall in the value of the pound against the US dollar, from around $1.09 to $1.03. The Bank of England, which had been considering hiking interest rates to combat inflation, announced an emergency meeting of its Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) to discuss the implications of the budget. The government's decision to cut taxes and increase borrowing was seen as raising the risk of inflation and increasing the national debt.

### **Bond markets**

The mini-budget caused a sharp sell-off in UK government bonds, pushing up yields and making borrowing more expensive for the government. The yield on 10-year gilts, which had been around 2.5% before the budget, rose to over 3.5% in the following days.

### **International response**

The international community was quick to react to the mini-budget, with many expressing concerns about the UK's economic policies. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) both warned that the UK's economic stance was high risk and could lead to economic instability.

### **Business and economic**

Business leaders and economists were divided in their reaction to the mini-budget. Some, such as the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), welcomed the measures as a boost to economic growth, while others, such as the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS), argued that the budget was unaffordable and would exacerbate the cost of living crisis.

### **Media**

The media reaction to the mini-budget was mixed, with some outlets welcoming the measures and others criticizing them. The BBC and other mainstream media outlets reported on the controversy and criticism surrounding the budget, while some right-wing outlets, such as the Daily Mail and the Sun, supported the government's stance.

### **Political**

The mini-budget sparked a major row within the Conservative Party, with some MPs expressing concerns about the budget's implications for the economy and the cost of living. The opposition parties, Labour and the Liberal Democrats, attacked the budget as reckless and unaffordable.

### **Opinion polling**

Opinion polls suggested that the public was divided on the mini-budget, with some seeing it as a boost to economic growth and others as a threat to the cost of living. A YouGov poll conducted in the days following the budget found that 34% of respondents supported the tax cuts, while 44% opposed them.

**Government response**

The government's response to the controversy surrounding the mini-budget was mixed.

### **Initial responses**

Initially, the government defended the mini-budget as a necessary measure to boost economic growth and combat inflation. Chancellor Kwarteng and Prime Minister Truss argued that the budget would create jobs and stimulate investment, making it easier for people to get on the housing ladder and pay off debt.

### **Dismissal of Chancellor**

However, as the controversy surrounding the budget continued to build, the government's tone shifted. On 14 October 2022, Prime Minister Truss announced that she would be firing Chancellor Kwarteng, replacing him with Jeremy Hunt.

### **Reversal of tax cuts**

As part of the shake-up, the government announced that it would be reversing some of the tax cuts announced in the mini-budget, including the 1% cut in National Insurance Contributions (NICs).

**Resignation of Truss as Prime Minister**

The controversy surrounding the mini-budget ultimately contributed to the resignation of Prime Minister Liz Truss as Conservative Party leader on 25 October 2022. Truss's decision to fire Chancellor Kwarteng and reverse the tax cuts was seen as a major U-turn, and opposition parties and some Tories argued that she had lost credibility.

**Subsequent events**

The aftermath of the mini-budget saw a major shake-up in the Conservative Party leadership, with new Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announcing a new economic strategy aimed at tackling the cost of living crisis.

### **Following Truss's resignation**

In the days following Truss's resignation, the Conservative Party leadership was in chaos. Several candidates, including Sunak and Penny Mordaunt, threw their hats into the ring, and the party's leadership election was marked by controversy and infighting.

### **Later events**

The mini-budget controversy marked a turning point in the UK's economic policy, with the government announcing a new strategy aimed at tackling inflation and the cost of living crisis. The budget's legacy continued to be felt, with the government's credibility and authority undermined by the controversy.

article:
**Varisu**

Varisu is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action drama film directed by Vamshi Paidipally and produced by Dil Raju under the banner of Sri Venkateswara Creations. The film stars Vijay in the lead role, alongside Rashmika Mandanna, Sarathkumar, Prabhu, and R. Sarathkumar in supporting roles. Varisu marks the second collaboration between Vijay and Vamshi Paidipally after the 2017 film Duvvada Jagannadham.

**Plot**

The story revolves around Arjun Reddy (Vijay), the eldest son of Bhagiratha Reddy (Prabhu), a wealthy businessman. Arjun returns to his hometown after spending a few years abroad and announces his intention to take over the family business. However, his father has other plans and wants him to take over a modest business. Arjun, who is used to a life of luxury, is initially reluctant but eventually agrees to take over the family business. As he sets out to prove himself, he faces numerous challenges and obstacles that test his resolve and determination.

* Vijay as Arjun Reddy
* Rashmika Mandanna as Bhavani
* Sarathkumar as Rishi Kumar
* Prabhu as Bhagiratha Reddy
* R. Sarathkumar as Bharath Reddy
* Shaam as Prashanth
* Sangeetha as Sailaja
* Varalaxmi Sarathkumar as Meenakshi
* Yogi Babu as Sundaram
* Rajendran as Inspector Dhanushkodi
* Sathyan as Kumar

**Production**

### Development

Varisu marks the second collaboration between Vijay and Vamshi Paidipally, who had previously worked together on the 2017 film Duvvada Jagannadham. The film was first announced in 2020, with Vijay and Rashmika Mandanna set to star in the lead roles. The film's script was written by Diamond Babu and K. T. Rama Rao, while the story was developed by Vamshi Paidipally.

### Casting

The casting process for Varisu began in 2020, with Vijay and Rashmika Mandanna being confirmed as the lead actors. The rest of the cast, including Sarathkumar, Prabhu, and R. Sarathkumar, were announced in the following months.

### Filming

Principal photography for Varisu began in July 2022 in Hyderabad, with Vijay and Rashmika Mandanna being spotted on set. The film's shoot was completed in December 2022, with the team shooting for over 150 days.

**Music**

The music for Varisu was composed by Thaman S, who had previously worked with Vijay on the films Sura and Theri. The soundtrack features six songs, including the title track "Varisu", which was released in January 2023. The song received a positive response from fans and critics alike, with many praising Thaman S' composition.

**Marketing**

The marketing campaign for Varisu began in January 2023, with the release of the film's first look poster. The poster featured Vijay in a powerful pose, with the film's title and release date announced in bold letters. The marketing campaign continued with the release of the film's trailer, which received a record number of views within the first 24 hours of its release.

**Release**

### Theatrical

Varisu was released in theaters on January 12, 2023, in over 4,000 screens across India. The film's release was a major event, with Vijay fans and supporters turning out in large numbers to watch the film.

### Distribution

The distribution rights for Varisu were acquired by Dil Raju's Sri Venkateswara Creations, who released the film in theaters. The film's distribution was handled by a team of experienced professionals, who worked tirelessly to ensure that the film was released smoothly in theaters.

### Pre-release business

The pre-release business for Varisu was a major success, with the film's satellite rights being sold for a record Rs 140 crore. The film's music rights were sold for Rs 12 crore, while the film's theatrical rights were sold for Rs 100 crore.

### Home media

Varisu was released on home media platforms on February 14, 2023, in digital and physical formats. The film's digital release was handled by Amazon Prime Video, while the physical release was handled by Sony Music.

**Reception**

Varisu received a positive response from critics and audiences alike. The film's action sequences, music, and performances were praised by critics, while the film's story and direction were criticized. The film's box office performance was also impressive, with the film grossing over Rs 200 crore in its opening weekend.

**Controversies**

Varisu was involved in several controversies during its release. The film's release was delayed due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, while the film's marketing campaign was criticized for being too aggressive. The film's music was also criticized for being too loud, while the film's action sequences were criticized for being too violent.

**Notes**

Varisu is a major commercial success, with the film grossing over Rs 500 crore worldwide. The film's success can be attributed to its strong performances, engaging storyline, and impressive action sequences.

**Endless Summer Vacation**

**Introduction**

Endless Summer Vacation is the seventh studio album by American singer-songwriter Mandy Moore, released on March 10, 2023, through Verve Records. The album marks Moore's first full-length release in over a decade, following her 2011 album Amanda Leigh. Produced by Joey Moi, the album features a mix of pop, rock, and country influences, with lyrics that explore themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. The album received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, with many praising Moore's return to music and the album's eclectic sound.

**Background and recording**

Moore began working on Endless Summer Vacation in early 2022, shortly after the release of her 2022 single "In Real Life". She has stated that the album was inspired by her own experiences of love, loss, and self-discovery, as well as her observations of the world around her. Moore worked with producer Joey Moi, who has also produced music for artists such as Keith Urban and Thomas Rhett. The album was recorded at various studios in Nashville, Tennessee, and Los Angeles, California.

Moore has stated that she took a more experimental approach to the album, incorporating a wider range of musical styles and influences than on her previous releases. She has cited artists such as Fleetwood Mac, The Eagles, and Taylor Swift as influences on the album's sound. The album features a mix of pop, rock, and country influences, with lyrics that explore themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery.

**Composition**

The album features 13 tracks, including the singles "In Real Life" and "She Said". The album's opening track, "In Real Life", is a pop-infused ballad that explores the theme of love and relationships. The second track, "She Said", is a country-tinged pop song that features a driving beat and a catchy chorus. The album's third track, "Leftovers", is a introspective ballad that explores the theme of heartbreak and self-discovery.

The album's middle tracks feature a mix of pop, rock, and country influences, with lyrics that explore themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. The album's seventh track, "Firefly", is a country-tinged pop song that features a driving beat and a catchy chorus. The eighth track, "Vulnerable", is a introspective ballad that explores the theme of vulnerability and self-discovery.

The album's final tracks feature a mix of pop, rock, and country influences, with lyrics that explore themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. The album's 12th track, "Oh My My My", is a pop-infused ballad that explores the theme of love and relationships. The album's final track, "Good News", is a country-tinged pop song that features a driving beat and a catchy chorus.

**Release and artwork**

Endless Summer Vacation was released on March 10, 2023, through Verve Records. The album's artwork features a photograph of Moore in a beach setting, surrounded by palm trees and a blue sky. The photograph was taken by photographer Alistair Taylor-Young. The album's cover art was designed by graphic designer Josh Pierce.

**Promotion**

Moore promoted Endless Summer Vacation through a series of interviews and performances. She appeared on various television shows, including The Ellen DeGeneres Show and Good Morning America. She also performed at various live events, including a concert at the Ryman Auditorium in Nashville, Tennessee.

Rolling Stone praised the album, stating that it was "a masterclass in mood and atmosphere". The magazine also praised Moore's vocals, stating that they were "hauntingly beautiful". Billboard praised the album, stating that it was "a stunning return to form" for Moore. The magazine also praised the album's production, stating that it was " cleverly crafted and nuanced".

The Los Angeles Times praised the album, stating that it was "a sophisticated and quietly powerful album". The newspaper also praised Moore's vocals, stating that they were "soaring and emotive". The New York Times praised the album, stating that it was "a beautifully crafted and deeply personal album".

article:
**2022 Asia Cup**

The 2022 Asia Cup was the 15th edition of the Asia Cup, a cricket tournament played among the national teams of the members of the Asian Cricket Council (ACC). It was held in the United Arab Emirates from August 27 to September 11, 2022.

**Background**

The Asia Cup is an international cricket tournament organized by the Asian Cricket Council (ACC) among the national teams of the members of the ACC. The tournament is contested by the top eight teams in the ACC, with the winner being crowned the champion of Asia. The 2022 Asia Cup was originally scheduled to be held in Sri Lanka, but due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in the country, the tournament was shifted to the United Arab Emirates.

**Teams and qualifications**

Eight teams participated in the 2022 Asia Cup:

1.  Afghanistan
2.  Bangladesh
3.  India
4.  Pakistan
5.  Sri Lanka
6.  United Arab Emirates
7.  Hong Kong
8.  Nepal

The teams were divided into two groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the Super Four stage.

**Squads**

Each team named a 15-player squad for the tournament. The squads were announced as follows:

1.  Afghanistan: Rashid Khan (c), Asghar Afghan, Hashmatullah Shahidi, Ihsanullah, Ibrahim Zadran, Karim Janat, Mohammad Nabi, Najibullah Zadran, Rahmat Shah, Rashid Khan, Sayed Shirzad, Sharafuddin Ashraf, Tariq Khan, Waheedullah Malik, Yamin Ahmadzai
2.  Bangladesh: Shakib Al Hasan (c), Anamul Haque, Afif Hossain, Ebadot Hossain, Hasan Mahmud, Liton Das, Mehidy Hasan, Mushfiqur Rahim, Mustafizur Rahman, Nasum Ahmed, Nurul Hasan, Rony Talukdar, Sabbir Alam, Taskin Ahmed, Yasir Ali
3.  India: Rohit Sharma (c), Shikhar Dhawan, Ravichandran Ashwin, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Deepak Chahar, Hardik Pandya, Ishan Kishan, KL Rahul, Kuldeep Yadav, Mohammed Siraj, R Ashwin, Ravindra Jadeja, Ruturaj Gaikwad, Shardul Thakur, Yuzvendra Chahal
4.  Pakistan: Babar Azam (c), Asif Ali, Fakhar Zaman, Haider Ali, Hasan Ali, Iftikhar Ahmed, Imad Wasim, Khushdil Shah, Mohammad Nawaz, Mohammad Rizwan, Shaheen Afridi, Shadab Khan, Shan Masood, Usman Qadir, Wasim Jr.
5.  Sri Lanka: Dasun Shanaka (c), Pathum Nissanka, Kusal Perera, Kusal Mendis, Dhananjaya de Silva, Charith Asalanka, Bhanuka Rajapaksa, Ramesh Mendis, Maheesh Theekshana, Dushmantha Chameera, Pramod Madushan, Jeffrey Vandersay, Kasun Rajitha, Nuwan Pradeep, Dilshan Madushanka
6.  United Arab Emirates: Muhammad Waseem (c), Chirag Suri, Aayan Khan, Rohan Mustafa, Rohan Janardhanan, Ashfaq Ahmed, Ahmed Raza, Jiteega Vasant, Basil Hameed, Faisal Altaf, Sultan Ahmed, Zahoor Khan, Karthik Meiyappan, Shaiman Anooq, Junaid Siddique
7.  Hong Kong: Nizakat Khan (c), Yasim Murtaza, Kinchit Shah, Ahsan Abidi, Ayush Maggo, Scott McKechnie, Babar Hayat, Christopher Carter, Rohan Mustafa, Ehsan Khan, Aizaz Khan, Scott MacPherson, Wajid Shah, Mohammad Ghazanfar, Haseeb Amjad
8.  Nepal: Rohit Kumar Paudel (c), Aasif Sheikh, Kushal Bhurtel, Dipesh Airee, Karan KC, Bhim Sharki, Gulsan Jha, Kushal Malla, Sompal Kami, Sandeep Lamichhane, Sagar Pun, Lalit Rajbanshi, Pratish GC, Kushal Bhurtel, Bibek Yadav

**Venues**

The tournament was played at the following venues in the United Arab Emirates:

1.  Dubai International Cricket Stadium, Dubai
2.  Dubai Sports City, Dubai
3.  Sharjah Cricket Stadium, Sharjah
4.  Zayed Cricket Stadium, Abu Dhabi

**Group stage**

The eight teams were divided into two groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the Super Four stage.

**Super Four**

**Historiography of the Christianization of the Roman Empire**

The Christianization of the Roman Empire is a complex and multifaceted process that has been studied by historians for centuries. The transformation of the Roman Empire from a pagan to a Christian society was a gradual and often contentious process that involved the interplay of various social, economic, and political factors. This article provides an overview of the historiography of the Christianization of the Roman Empire, exploring the different approaches, theories, and interpretations that have been proposed by historians to explain this significant historical event.

# History

## Of historiography

The study of the Christianization of the Roman Empire is a subfield of historical inquiry that has undergone significant changes in approach and interpretation over the centuries. In the early days of Christian historiography, the focus was on the heroic narrative of the early Christian martyrs and the triumph of Christianity over paganism. This narrative was often presented in a simplistic and triumphalist manner, emphasizing the role of key figures such as Constantine and the apostles in spreading Christianity throughout the empire.

## Roman religion

### Context and other evidence

As historians began to study the Roman Empire in a more nuanced and systematic way, they realized that the Christianization of the empire was not a sudden or isolated event, but rather a complex process that was influenced by a variety of social, economic, and cultural factors. Roman religion, in particular, played a significant role in shaping the context in which Christianity emerged and spread. The Roman pantheon of gods and goddesses was vast and complex, with a multitude of deities and rituals that were worshipped throughout the empire.

Roman religion was characterized by a syncretic approach to spirituality, with many Romans incorporating elements of different cults and traditions into their own religious practices. This syncretism allowed for a degree of flexibility and adaptability in the Roman approach to spirituality, which may have helped to pave the way for the eventual acceptance of Christianity as a dominant faith.

## Spread of Christianity

### Origin

The origin of Christianity is a topic of ongoing debate and research among historians. While the New Testament accounts of the life and teachings of Jesus Christ provide a rich and detailed narrative of the early Christian community, there is ongoing debate about the historical accuracy and reliability of these accounts.

Some historians have suggested that Christianity emerged from a Jewish context, with Jesus and his followers drawing on Jewish scripture and tradition to develop their own distinct faith. Others have proposed that Christianity was influenced by other Mediterranean cults and traditions, such as the cult of Mithras or the worship of Isis.

### Reception and growth in Roman society

As Christianity began to spread throughout the Roman Empire, it faced significant challenges and obstacles from both within and outside the faith community. Many Romans saw Christianity as a threat to traditional Roman values and institutions, and the early Christian community faced persecution and martyrdom at the hands of Roman authorities.

Despite these challenges, Christianity continued to grow and spread throughout the empire, with many converts coming from the ranks of the urban poor and marginalized communities. The Christian community also began to develop its own distinct institutions and practices, including the establishment of churches, the development of a liturgy, and the creation of a distinct Christian calendar.

### Under Constantine and his Christian successors

The conversion of Constantine to Christianity in the early 4th century marked a significant turning point in the history of the Roman Empire. Constantine's decision to adopt Christianity as the official state religion of the empire helped to establish Christianity as a dominant faith and paved the way for the eventual Christianization of the empire.

Constantine's successors, including his son Constantius II and his grandson Theodosius I, continued to promote Christianity throughout the empire. They established Christian schools and universities, promoted the development of Christian art and architecture, and sponsored the translation of Christian texts into Latin and other languages.

### Theodosius I

Theodosius I, also known as Theodosius the Great, was one of the most important figures in the Christianization of the Roman Empire. He was the last emperor to rule over a unified Roman Empire and was responsible for establishing Christianity as the official state religion of the empire.

Theodosius I was a devout Christian who saw himself as a champion of the faith. He promulgated a series of laws and edicts that promoted Christianity throughout the empire, including the Edict of Thessalonica, which established Christianity as the official state religion of the empire.

### Theodosius II and Pope Leo I

Theodosius II, the son of Theodosius I, continued to promote Christianity throughout the empire. He established the Council of Chalcedon in 451, which helped to establish the doctrine of the Trinity and the nature of Christ.

Pope Leo I, who served as pope from 440 to 461, played a significant role in the Christianization of the Roman Empire. He was a strong advocate for the doctrine of the Trinity and the nature of Christ, and his letters and sermons helped to shape the theological debates of the time.

### Sixth to eighth centuries

The sixth to eighth centuries were a time of significant change and upheaval in the Roman Empire. The empire was beset by internal conflicts, external invasions, and economic decline, which led to a decline in the power and influence of the Roman state.

Despite these challenges, Christianity continued to grow and spread throughout the empire. The Christian community became increasingly institutionalized, with the establishment of monasteries, churches, and other Christian institutions.

# Mathematical modelling

Mathematical modelling has been used to study the spread of Christianity throughout the Roman Empire. One approach is to use network theory to model the spread of Christianity as a process of diffusion through a network of social connections.

Another approach is to use epidemiological models to study the spread of Christianity as a process of infection and contagion. These models can help to identify the key factors that contributed to the spread of Christianity, such as the role of social networks, the influence of leaders, and the impact of external events.

# Possible reasons for a top-down spread

## Traditional conflict models

Traditional conflict models suggest that the spread of Christianity was facilitated by the use of violence and coercion by Christian leaders and authorities. This approach emphasizes the role of power and authority in shaping the spread of Christianity.

## Violence and temple destruction

The use of violence and temple destruction has been cited as a key factor in the spread of Christianity. Many early Christian writers, including Eusebius and Jerome, emphasized the role of martyrdom and persecution in shaping the identity and purpose of the Christian community.

## Socio-economic factors

Socio-economic factors, such as poverty and social marginalization, may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. Many early Christian converts came from the ranks of the urban poor and marginalized communities, who may have seen Christianity as a means of escaping their social and economic circumstances.

## Influence of legislation

The influence of legislation, such as the Edict of Milan and the Edict of Thessalonica, may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. These edicts helped to establish Christianity as the official state religion of the empire and provided a framework for the promotion of Christianity throughout the empire.

# Possible reasons for a grassroots spread

## New ideas

New ideas, such as the teachings of Jesus and the apostles, may have contributed to the spread of Christianity. The Christian message of love, compassion, and forgiveness may have resonated with people who were seeking a more personal and spiritual connection with the divine.

## Inclusivity and exclusivity

The Christian message of inclusivity and exclusivity may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The Christian community was seen as a welcoming and inclusive community that offered a sense of belonging and identity to its members.

## Kerygma (central message)

The kerygma, or central message, of Christianity may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The Christian message of salvation and redemption may have resonated with people who were seeking a sense of hope and purpose in their lives.

# Social practices

## Women

Women played a significant role in the spread of Christianity. Many early Christian women, such as Thecla and Perpetua, were prominent figures in the Christian community and helped to shape the identity and purpose of the faith.

## Sexual morality

The Christian teachings on sexual morality may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The Christian emphasis on chastity and virginity may have resonated with people who were seeking a more spiritual and disciplined approach to sex and relationships.

## Care for the poor

The Christian emphasis on care for the poor and marginalized may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The Christian community was seen as a welcoming and inclusive community that offered a sense of belonging and identity to its members.

## Health care

The Christian emphasis on health care may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The Christian community was seen as a place where people could receive medical care and spiritual support.

## Community

The Christian community was seen as a welcoming and inclusive community that offered a sense of belonging and identity to its members. The Christian community was characterized by a sense of shared values and purpose, and a commitment to caring for one another.

## Martyrdom

The Christian tradition of martyrdom may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The willingness of Christians to sacrifice their lives for their faith may have inspired others to join the faith and to stand up for their rights and freedoms.

## Miracles

The Christian tradition of miracles may have also contributed to the spread of Christianity. The reported miracles and healings associated with Christian leaders and saints may have helped to establish the credibility and authority of the Christian faith.

# Alternative approaches

## Network theory

Network theory has been used to study the spread of Christianity as a process of diffusion through a network of social connections. This approach emphasizes the role of social networks and relationships in shaping the spread of Christianity.

## Psychology

Psychological approaches have been used to study the motivations and behaviors of individuals who join the Christian faith. This approach emphasizes the role of personal experiences, emotions, and cognitive processes in shaping the decision to become a Christian.

## Evolution

Evolutionary approaches have been used to study the development and spread of Christianity over time. This approach emphasizes the role of natural selection and adaptation in shaping the Christian faith and its distinctive characteristics.

## Diffusion of innovation

Diffusion of innovation approaches have been used to study the spread of Christianity as a process of innovation and diffusion. This approach emphasizes the role of individual innovators and early adopters in shaping the spread of Christianity.

# Effects

## Judicial penalties and clemency

The Christianization of the Roman Empire had significant effects on the judicial system. The Christian emphasis on forgiveness and mercy may have led to a decrease in the use of capital punishment and other harsh penalties.

## Slavery

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of slavery. The Christian emphasis on the dignity and worth of all human beings may have led to a decrease in the use of slavery and a greater emphasis on the importance of individual freedom.

## Persecution of heretics

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the persecution of heretics. The Christian emphasis on orthodoxy and the rejection of heresy may have led to a increase in the persecution of individuals and groups who were seen as heretics.

## Corruption

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of corruption. The Christian emphasis on honesty and integrity may have led to a decrease in corruption and a greater emphasis on the importance of moral and ethical behavior.

## Gladiator games

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of gladiator games. The Christian emphasis on compassion and mercy may have led to a decrease in the use of gladiator games and a greater emphasis on the importance of human life.

## Intolerance

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of intolerance. The Christian emphasis on love and acceptance may have led to a decrease in intolerance and a greater emphasis on the importance of understanding and empathy.

## Difference in sexual morality

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of sexual morality. The Christian emphasis on chastity and virginity may have led to a decrease in promiscuity and a greater emphasis on the importance of monogamy.

## Sanctity of life

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of the sanctity of life. The Christian emphasis on the value and dignity of human life may have led to a greater emphasis on the importance of protecting human life and preventing unnecessary violence and harm.

## Education

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of education. The Christian emphasis on knowledge and understanding may have led to a greater emphasis on the importance of education and the development of critical thinking skills.

## Sociological effects

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant sociological effects. The Christian emphasis on community and social responsibility may have led to a greater sense of social cohesion and a greater emphasis on the importance of caring for one another.

## Law

The Christianization of the Roman Empire also had significant effects on the institution of law. The Christian emphasis on justice and fairness may have led to a greater emphasis on the importance of protecting individual rights and freedoms and preventing abuses of power.

article:
Archie Battersbee Case

The Archie Battersbee case refers to a series of legal and medical disputes surrounding the life and treatment of Archie Battersbee, a 12-year-old boy from Southend-on-Sea, England. The case began in April 2022 and continued for over a year, involving multiple court judgments, inquests, and interventions from various organizations and individuals.

**Incident**

Archie Battersbee suffered a severe brain injury in April 2022, reportedly after attempting to take his own life by hanging. He was found unresponsive by his mother, Hollie Dance, and was taken to the Royal London Hospital. Archie's treatment and care became a subject of controversy, with his parents and medical professionals disagreeing on the best course of action.

**Legal cases**

The Archie Battersbee case involved multiple legal proceedings, including several court judgments and appeals. The initial dispute centered on Archie's treatment, with his parents seeking to have him transferred to a different hospital for further care. The court ultimately ruled in favor of the hospital, citing Archie's best interests as the primary consideration.

However, the case took a significant turn in May 2022 when Archie's parents, Hollie Dance and Paul Battersbee, applied to the High Court for a "fresh" assessment of Archie's condition. They argued that the initial assessment had been incomplete and that Archie's condition had deteriorated since then. The court eventually ruled in favor of the parents, ordering a new assessment of Archie's condition.

**Inquest**

In addition to the legal proceedings, an inquest was also held into Archie's death. The inquest, which was initially scheduled for 2023, was delayed due to the ongoing legal disputes surrounding Archie's treatment. The inquest ultimately took place in 2023, with a jury delivering a verdict on the circumstances surrounding Archie's death.

**Timeline**

### April 2022

* Archie Battersbee suffers a severe brain injury, reportedly after attempting to take his own life by hanging.
* Archie is taken to the Royal London Hospital, where he is placed on life support.
* Archie's parents, Hollie Dance and Paul Battersbee, begin to dispute the hospital's treatment of their son.

### May 2022

* Archie's parents apply to the High Court for a "fresh" assessment of Archie's condition.

* The hospital begins to transfer Archie to a different ward, citing concerns for his safety.

### June 2022

* Archie's parents launch a GoFundMe page to raise money for their son's treatment.
* The Christian Legal Centre becomes involved in the case, supporting Archie's parents in their dispute with the hospital.

### July 2022

* The court delivers a judgment on Archie's treatment, ruling that he should remain on life support.
* Archie's parents launch a formal complaint against the hospital, citing alleged breaches of Archie's human rights.

### August 2022

* The hospital announces plans to withdraw life support from Archie, citing his poor prognosis.
* Archie's parents launch an appeal against the hospital's decision, citing concerns for their son's safety.

### September 2022

* The court delivers a judgment on Archie's appeal, ruling that the hospital can withdraw life support.
* Archie's parents announce plans to take their case to the European Court of Human Rights.

### November 2022

* The European Court of Human Rights delivers a judgment on Archie's case, ruling that the hospital's decision to withdraw life support was lawful.
* Archie's parents announce plans to take their case to the Court of Appeal.

### February 2023

* The Court of Appeal delivers a judgment on Archie's case, ruling that the hospital's decision to withdraw life support was lawful.
* Archie's parents announce that they have exhausted all avenues of appeal.

**Summary of judgments**

The Archie Battersbee case involved multiple court judgments and appeals. The initial dispute centered on Archie's treatment, with his parents seeking to have him transferred to a different hospital for further care. The court ultimately ruled in favor of the hospital, citing Archie's best interests as the primary consideration. However, the case took a significant turn in May 2022 when Archie's parents applied for a "fresh" assessment of Archie's condition. The court eventually ruled in favor of the parents, ordering a new assessment of Archie's condition.

**Third party involvement and media analysis**

### Christian Legal Centre

The Christian Legal Centre became involved in the case, supporting Archie's parents in their dispute with the hospital. The organization argued that the hospital's decision to withdraw life support from Archie was unlawful and breached his human rights.

### MP's letter for treatment abroad

An MP wrote to the hospital, urging them to consider transferring Archie to a different hospital for further treatment. The letter cited concerns for Archie's safety and well-being.

### GoFundMe page

Archie's parents launched a GoFundMe page to raise money for their son's treatment. The page raised over £500,000, with donations coming from around the world.

**Family campaigns**

Archie's parents, Hollie Dance and Paul Battersbee, campaigned tirelessly for their son's rights and safety. They worked with various organizations and individuals to raise awareness and support for their cause.

article:
**2022 Gujarat Legislative Assembly election**

The 2022 Gujarat Legislative Assembly election was held on December 1 and 5, 2022, to elect the members of the 15th Gujarat Legislative Assembly. The election was contested by several political parties, including the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), the Indian National Congress (INC), and the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP).

**Background**

In the run-up to the election, the state of Gujarat was experiencing a series of local body elections, which were seen as a precursor to the assembly elections. The local body elections saw a significant number of Congress candidates winning, which was seen as a sign of the party's resurgence in the state.

**Schedule**

The election schedule was announced by the Election Commission of India (ECI) on October 29, 2022. The election was to be held in two phases, with the first phase covering 89 constituencies on December 1, 2022, and the second phase covering the remaining 93 constituencies on December 5, 2022.

**Election statistics**

The election saw a total of 4,144 candidates contesting for the 182 assembly seats. The number of voters was approximately 4.8 crore, with a total of 5.4 crore eligible voters. The election was held using Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs), with the counting of votes taking place on December 8, 2022.

**Parties and alliances**

Several political parties and alliances contested the election, including:

### **Bharatiya Janata Party**

The BJP was the ruling party in the state and was seeking a sixth consecutive term in office. The party's campaign focused on the development work done by the government and the need for stability and continuity. The party's manifesto promised to create more jobs, improve healthcare and education, and increase farmer support.

### **United Progressive Alliance**

The United Progressive Alliance (UPA) was an alliance of opposition parties, including the INC, the Nationalist Congress Party (NCP), and the Indian Union Muslim League (IUML). The alliance's campaign focused on the need for a change in government and the promise of better governance and development.

### **Aam Aadmi Party**

The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) was a new entrant in the state and was seeking to make a mark in the election. The party's campaign focused on the need for a corruption-free government and the promise of better governance and development. The party's manifesto promised to create more jobs, improve healthcare and education, and increase farmer support.

### **Others**

Other parties and alliances that contested the election included the Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP), the Samajwadi Party (SP), the Communist Party of India (CPI), and the Communist Party of India (Marxist) (CPM).

**Candidates**

A total of 4,144 candidates contested the election, including several high-profile candidates. The number of women candidates was 961, which was a record high for the state.

**Issues**

Several issues dominated the election campaign, including:

### **Alcohol**

The issue of prohibition and the impact of liquor consumption on the state was a major issue in the election. The BJP government had banned the sale of liquor in the state in 2017, but the move was widely criticized and eventually rolled back.

### **Drugs**

The issue of drug addiction and the impact of substance abuse on the state was also a major issue in the election. The government had launched several initiatives to tackle the problem, including the setting up of rehabilitation centers and the creation of a state-level task force to combat drug trafficking.

### **Corruption**

The issue of corruption was a major issue in the election, with several candidates promising to tackle the problem and create a transparent and accountable government.

### **Agriculture**

The issue of agriculture and the impact of climate change on the sector was also a major issue in the election. The government had launched several initiatives to support farmers, including the creation of a state-level committee to help farmers deal with the impact of climate change.

### **Unemployment**

The issue of unemployment and the need for job creation was a major issue in the election. The government had launched several initiatives to create jobs, including the setting up of a state-level employment exchange and the creation of a portal to connect job seekers with employers.

### **Education**

The issue of education and the need for better infrastructure and facilities was a major issue in the election. The government had launched several initiatives to improve education, including the creation of a state-level committee to monitor the implementation of the Right to Education Act.

### **Price Rise**

The issue of price rise and the impact of inflation on the state was also a major issue in the election. The government had launched several initiatives to control inflation, including the creation of a state-level task force to monitor prices and the setting up of a portal to track price movements.

**Campaigns**

Several parties launched campaigns to woo voters, including:

### **Aam Aadmi Party**

The AAP launched a campaign titled "5 guarantees" which promised to provide 5 guarantees to the people of Gujarat, including a corruption-free government, a pension of Rs. 1,000 per month for every citizen, a guarantee of 300 units of free electricity, a guarantee of 200 units of free water, and a guarantee of free education and healthcare.

### **Bharatiya Janata Party**

The BJP launched a campaign titled "BJP ka Gujarat" which promised to create a prosperous and developed Gujarat under the leadership of Chief Minister Vijay Rupani.

### **Indian National Congress**

The INC launched a campaign titled "Congress ki Gujarat ki Badhaai" which promised to create a Gujarat which is free from corruption and where the poor are treated with dignity.

**Incidents**

Several incidents marred the election campaign, including:

### **Aam Aadmi Party**

The AAP faced several allegations of poll code violations, including the distribution of freebies and the use of paid news.

### **Bharatiya Janata Party**

The BJP faced several allegations of poll code violations, including the use of paid news and the distribution of freebies.

### **Indian National Congress**

The INC faced several allegations of poll code violations, including the use of paid news and the distribution of freebies.

### **Others**

Several other parties and alliances also faced allegations of poll code violations, including the BSP, the SP, the CPI, and the CPM.

**Surveys and polls**

Several surveys and polls were conducted during the election campaign, including:

### **Opinion polls**

Several opinion polls were conducted by various agencies, including the Lokniti-CSDS, the CSDS-Lokniti, and the CSDS-POLL.

### **Exit polls**

Several exit polls were conducted by various agencies, including the India Today-Axis, the Times Now-VMR, and the CNN-IBN-CSDS.

**Voter turnout**

The voter turnout in the election was approximately 63%, which was a record high for the state.

**Results**

The results of the election were declared on December 8, 2022, and the BJP emerged as the single largest party, winning 111 seats. The AAP won 15 seats, while the INC won 17 seats. The results by alliance and party were:

article:
**Plotinus**

Plotinus (c. 205 – 270 AD) was a Greek philosopher who founded the Platonic School in Rome, which became a major center of Neoplatonism. He is considered one of the most influential philosophers of late antiquity, and his ideas had a significant impact on the development of Western philosophy, particularly in the areas of metaphysics, epistemology, and the nature of the human soul.

**Biography**

Plotinus was born in Lycopolis, Egypt, around 205 AD. Little is known about his early life, but it is believed that he was educated in rhetoric and philosophy in Alexandria, where he became familiar with the works of Plato. He traveled extensively throughout the ancient world, including a journey to Persia, where he may have encountered the teachings of the Persian prophet Mani.

### Expedition to Persia and return to Rome

During his expedition to Persia, Plotinus may have been exposed to various mystical and philosophical traditions, including the teachings of the Gnostics and the Zoroastrians. The exact nature of his experiences during this period is unclear, but it is believed that he was deeply influenced by the spiritual and philosophical ideas he encountered. After his return to Rome, Plotinus established a philosophical school, which attracted a diverse range of students from various backgrounds.

### Later life

Plotinus's later life was marked by a series of intellectual and spiritual struggles. He was deeply concerned with the nature of the human soul and the path to spiritual enlightenment. He spent many years developing his philosophical system, which he believed would lead to a deeper understanding of the universe and the human condition. Plotinus died in 270 AD, at the age of 65, and his school was eventually closed by the Emperor Constantine in 313 AD.

**Major ideas**

Plotinus's philosophical system is centered around the concept of the One, which he believed was the ultimate reality and the source of all being. He developed a complex and nuanced view of the universe, which he believed was characterized by a series of emanations from the One.

### The One

The One is the ultimate reality and the source of all being. It is the infinite, eternal, and unchanging essence that underlies all existence. Plotinus believed that the One is beyond human comprehension, but that it can be experienced through a process of spiritual purification and contemplation.

### Emanation by the One

Plotinus believed that the One emanates a series of lesser realities, including the Intellect, the Soul, and the material world. These emanations are not separate from the One, but rather are aspects of its being. The process of emanation is a gradual one, with each stage becoming increasingly distant from the One.

### The true human and happiness

Plotinus believed that the true human is the one who has achieved spiritual enlightenment and has become united with the One. This state of unity is characterized by a sense of freedom, joy, and happiness, which is unshakeable and unchanging. The true human is beyond the concerns of the material world and is focused solely on the pursuit of spiritual knowledge and understanding.

### Henosis

Henosis is the process of spiritual purification and contemplation that leads to unity with the One. It involves the rejection of the material world and the cultivation of virtues such as wisdom, courage, and self-control. Henosis is a gradual process that requires dedication, discipline, and a deep commitment to spiritual growth.

**Relation with contemporary philosophy and religion**

Plotinus's philosophical system was deeply influenced by the teachings of Plato, whom he considered to be the greatest philosopher of all time. He was also influenced by the Gnostics, with whom he shared a deep concern with the nature of the human soul and the path to spiritual enlightenment.

### Plotinus's Relation to Plato

Plotinus saw himself as a faithful interpreter of Plato's teachings, and his philosophical system was deeply influenced by the Platonic tradition. He believed that Plato's philosophy was a revelation of the truth, and that it provided a framework for understanding the nature of reality and the human condition.

### Plotinus and the Gnostics

Plotinus was deeply concerned with the nature of the human soul and the path to spiritual enlightenment, which was also a central concern of the Gnostics. However, while the Gnostics believed in a radical separation between the material and spiritual worlds, Plotinus believed in a more nuanced view, in which the material world was seen as a necessary aspect of the spiritual journey.

### Against causal astrology

Plotinus rejected the idea of causal astrology, which posits that the movements of the stars and planets have a causal influence on human affairs. He believed that human beings have free will and are responsible for their own actions, and that the movements of the stars and planets are simply a reflection of the natural order of the universe.

Plotinus's philosophical system has been the subject of various film studies, which have attempted to capture the essence of his ideas on the screen. These films often feature a protagonist who is on a journey of spiritual discovery, and who must confront the challenges of the material world in order to achieve unity with the One.

**Influence**

Plotinus's philosophical system has had a significant impact on the development of Western philosophy, particularly in the areas of metaphysics, epistemology, and the nature of the human soul. His ideas have influenced a wide range of thinkers, from the Christian theologians of the early Middle Ages to the modern philosophers of the Enlightenment.

### Ancient world

In the ancient world, Plotinus's philosophical system was influential in the development of Neoplatonism, which became a major center of intellectual and spiritual inquiry. His ideas were also influential in the development of Gnosticism, which emphasized the importance of spiritual knowledge and the rejection of the material world.

Plotinus's ideas were influential in the development of Christian theology, particularly in the areas of the nature of the Trinity and the concept of the divine. The Battle of Donbas (2022) was a major military conflict that took place in the Donbas region of Ukraine, between the Ukrainian military and Russian-backed separatist forces, as well as regular Russian military units. The conflict began in April 2022, as part of the larger 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, and lasted for several months, with periods of intense fighting and Russian operational pauses.

The Donbas region, located in eastern Ukraine, has been a major point of contention between Ukraine and Russia since the 2014 Ukrainian revolution, which led to the ousting of pro-Russian President Viktor Yanukovych. In 2022, the conflict escalated into a full-scale war, with Russia launching a large-scale invasion of Ukraine.
